mentions.context: ECMT works for the French language.
ECMT does not allow one to choose the ontology to be used by the annotation process.
SIFR (Semantic Indexing of French Biomedical Data Resources -http://bioportal.lirmm.fr/annotator)
Pymm parses the XML output of MetaMap.
ECMT is licensed by the University Hospital of Rouen, France and it was possible to process data locally.
SIFR bioportal is openly accessible and offers docker packaging.
ECMT
ECMT + SIFR, or cTAKES + MetaMap) are more frequent than in case of "multilingual" intersection (e.g.
ECMT + cTAKES, or SIFR + MetaMap, etc.) (See Table 1).
cTAKES did not exhibit as good results as MetaMap on our selection but this might be explained by the fact that we used the default clinical pipeline.
cTAKES allows to create and customize pipelines according to the context.
MetaMap maps text parts to concepts from the UMLS Metathesaurus.
MetaMap [7] was developed by the National Library of Medicine to map biomedical texts to concepts in the Unified Medical Language System (UMLS).

cTAKES [8]  ECMT (Extracteur de Concepts Multi-Terminologiquehttp://ecmt.chu-rouen.fr) is a web service inspired by the CISMef algorithm for information retrieval with the Doc'CISMeF search engine and F-MTI [10] which is a multiterminology automatic indexer.
x SIFR: the UMLS CUI, the matched concept, and negation were extracted from the json files
x ECMT: the matched concept, the terminology from which it was retrieved, and its code in that terminology were extracted from the XML output.
x ECMT can annotate phrases that are specific to the French language since it uses French terminologies for the indexation.
x SIFR offers access to multiple terminologies and ontologies, including those that are specific to the oncological field (e.g., MuEVo).
x cTAKES can be customized according to the clinical needs and can be performant in terms of breast cancer clinical data extraction (DeepPhe pipeline [15]).
x MetaMap could produce more information like HER status, hormonal receptors and numeric information like tumor size.
The ECMT output is an XML file that contains the identified concepts in the seven terminologies used by ECMT.
For MetaMap, we used the Python wrapper Pymm for extracting candidate and mapping concepts.
ECMT + SIFR, or cTAKES + MetaMap) are more frequent than in case of "multilingual" intersection (e.g.
ECMT + cTAKES, or SIFR + MetaMap, etc.) (See Table 1).
In order to run cTAKES and MetaMap, we had to translate BCPSs from French to English.

We observed that MetaMap extracted the largest number of UMLS concepts (15,458), followed by SIFR (3,784), ECMT (1,962), and cTAKES (1,769).
ECMT + cTAKES, or SIFR + MetaMap, etc.) (See Table 1).
For the French language, SIFR extracted most of the concepts extracted by ECMT, but also retrieved more concepts.
ECMT + SIFR, or cTAKES + MetaMap) are more frequent than in case of "multilingual" intersection (e.g.
ECMT + cTAKES, or SIFR + MetaMap, etc.) (See Table 1).
Many components bundled in cTAKES are available and can be used in multiple ways.
In order to run cTAKES and MetaMap, we had to translate BCPSs from French to English.
The fact that the version of ECMT we used did not provide the UMLS CUIs was constraining for comparing annotators, but using SIFR to extract CUIs was a practical solution to overcome this difficulty.
Pymm parses the XML output of MetaMap.
A.Redjdal  et al. / Comparison of MetaMap, cTAKES, SIFR, and ECMT to Annotate Breast Cancer Patient Summaries
We processed the files using a Python parser and generated a table with four columns: extracted concept, UMLS CUI, negation, and subject.
For MetaMap, we used the Python wrapper Pymm for extracting candidate and mapping concepts.
cTAKES did not exhibit as good results as MetaMap on our selection but this might be explained by the fact that we used the default clinical pipeline.
A.Redjdal  et al. / Comparison of MetaMap, cTAKES, SIFR, and ECMT to Annotate Breast Cancer Patient Summaries

On the 25 BCPS-selection, we observed that MetaMap was the system that extracted the largest number of UMLS concepts (15,458), SIFR is the annotator with the second higher number of concepts extracted (3,784), followed by ECMT (1,962), and cTAKES (1,769).
Post-treatment of the outputs of each system cTAKES outputs are XMI files, readable using the UIMA CAS Visual Debugger (CVD).
For the two French annotators, we implemented a script that takes the output of each system and processes it:
A.Redjdal  et al. / Comparison of MetaMap, cTAKES, SIFR, and ECMT to Annotate Breast Cancer Patient Summaries
A.Redjdal  et al. / Comparison of MetaMap, cTAKES, SIFR, and ECMT to Annotate Breast Cancer Patient Summaries
For the French language, SIFR extracted most of the concepts extracted by ECMT, but also retrieved more concepts.
The annotator can be used via a REST-API, the workflow generates a final json-ld output or converts it to different formats (e.g., BRAT).

Annotators have been developed to extract the relevant content of such documents, e.g., MetaMap and cTAKES, that work with the English language and perform concept mapping using UMLS, SIFR and ECMT, that work for the French language and provide concepts using various terminologies.
We observed that MetaMap extracted the largest number of UMLS concepts (15,458), followed by SIFR (3,784), ECMT (1,962), and cTAKES (1,769).
Currently, two systems [6] are widely used in the biomedical field for the English language, MetaMap [7] and cTAKES [8].
Post-treatment of the outputs of each system cTAKES outputs are XMI files, readable using the UIMA CAS Visual Debugger (CVD).

Annotators have been developed to extract the relevant content of such documents, e.g., MetaMap and cTAKES, that work with the English language and perform concept mapping using UMLS, SIFR and ECMT, that work for the French language and provide concepts using various terminologies.
The ECMT output is an XML file that contains the identified concepts in the seven terminologies used by ECMT.
We observed that MetaMap extracted the largest number of UMLS concepts (15,458), followed by SIFR (3,784), ECMT (1,962), and cTAKES (1,769).
Currently, two systems [6] are widely used in the biomedical field for the English language, MetaMap [7] and cTAKES [8].
Since we will work on a corpus of French BCPSs, we considered two systems that work for the French language, i.e., SIFR [9] and ECMT [10].

When analysing all extracted concepts, we found out that, in addition to retrieving the greatest number of concepts, Met-aMap extracted multiple useful data for the cancer domain, e.g., hormonal receptors values or tumor size when mentioned in the text.

cTAKES [8]  ECMT (Extracteur de Concepts Multi-Terminologiquehttp://ecmt.chu-rouen.fr) is a web service inspired by the CISMef algorithm for information retrieval with the Doc'CISMeF search engine and F-MTI [10] which is a multiterminology automatic indexer.

The raw use of annotators of the full content of BCPSs only provides a list of concepts, asserted or negated (except for ECMT at present), but misses contextual information that could support a better data structuration.

In order to compare the results by using the UMLS CUIs to avoid problems in the translation of the matched text, we reused SIFR on the words and phrases matched by ECMT so we could obtain, if available, the UMLS CUIs for the concepts extracted by ECMT.
The fact that the version of ECMT we used did not provide the UMLS CUIs was constraining for comparing annotators, but using SIFR to extract CUIs was a practical solution to overcome this difficulty.
We observed that MetaMap extracted the largest number of UMLS concepts (15,458), followed by SIFR (3,784), ECMT (1,962), and cTAKES (1,769).

On the 25 BCPS-selection, we observed that MetaMap was the system that extracted the largest number of UMLS concepts (15,458), SIFR is the annotator with the second higher number of concepts extracted (3,784), followed by ECMT (1,962), and cTAKES (1,769).
Since we will work on a corpus of French BCPSs, we considered two systems that work for the French language, i.e., SIFR [9] and ECMT [10].

In order to compare the results by using the UMLS CUIs to avoid problems in the translation of the matched text, we reused SIFR on the words and phrases matched by ECMT so we could obtain, if available, the UMLS CUIs for the concepts extracted by ECMT.

Annotators have been developed to extract the relevant content of such documents, e.g., MetaMap and cTAKES, that work with the English language and perform concept mapping using UMLS, SIFR and ECMT, that work for the French language and provide concepts using various terminologies.

On the 25 BCPS-selection, we observed that MetaMap was the system that extracted the largest number of UMLS concepts (15,458), SIFR is the annotator with the second higher number of concepts extracted (3,784), followed by ECMT (1,962), and cTAKES (1,769).

On the 25 BCPS-selection, we observed that MetaMap was the system that extracted the largest number of UMLS concepts (15,458), SIFR is the annotator with the second higher number of concepts extracted (3,784), followed by ECMT (1,962), and cTAKES (1,769).

In order to compare the results by using the UMLS CUIs to avoid problems in the translation of the matched text, we reused SIFR on the words and phrases matched by ECMT so we could obtain, if available, the UMLS CUIs for the concepts extracted by ECMT.
